{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} [[File:Landfalling New York hurricanes.png|400px|thumb|Track map of all storms known to have made landfall in the state of New York]] 84 tropical or subtropical [[cyclone]]s have affected the state of [[New York State|New York]] since the 17th century. The state of New York is located along the [[East Coast of the United States]], in the [[Northeastern United States|Northeastern]] portion of the country. The strongest of these storms was the [[1938 New England hurricane]], which struck [[Long Island]] as a Category 3 storm on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]]. Killing more than 600 people, it was also the deadliest. Tropical cyclones have affected the state primarily in September but have also hit during every month of the hurricane season, June through November. Tropical cyclones rarely make landfall on the state, although it is common for remnants of tropical cyclones to produce heavy rainfall and flooding.
==Before 1800== * between 1278 and 1438 — A major hurricane struck the modern-day New York/New Jersey area.<ref name="Donnelly2001">{{cite journal |last=Donnelly |first=Jeffrey P. |authorlink= |year=2001 |title=Sedimentary evidence of intense hurricane strikes from New Jersey |journal=Geology |volume=29 |issue=7 |pages=615–618 |doi=10.1130/0091-7613(2001)029<0615:SEOIHS>2.0.CO;2 |url= |accessdate= |quote= |bibcode = 2001Geo....29..615D |display-authors=1 |last2=Roll |first2=Stuart |last3=Wengren |first3=Micah |last4=Butler |first4=Jessica |last5=Lederer |first5=Richard |last6=Webb |first6=Thompson }}</ref> * August 25, 1635 — A hurricane that is reported to have tracked parallel to the East Coast impacts [[New England]] and [[New York (state)|New York]], although it remains unknown if any damage occurred.<ref name="disc1">{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=History of Virginia Hurricanes|year=2006|publisher=Hydrological Prediction Center|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/va17hur.htm}}</ref> * September 8, 1667 — A 'severe storm' is reported in [[Manhattan]] and is reported to be a continuation of a powerful hurricane which affected the [[Mid-Atlantic states|Mid-Atlantic]].<ref name="disc1"/> * October 29, 1693 — The Great Storm of 1693 causes severe damage on Long Island, and is reported to create the [[Fire Island]] Cut as a result of the coast-changing storm surge and waves.<ref name="disc1"/><ref name="disc2">{{cite web|author=Weather2000|title=Hurricanes Impacting the New York coast|year=2006|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://www.weather2000.com/NY_Hurricanes.html}}</ref> * September 23, 1785 — Several large ships crash into [[Governors Island]] as a result of powerful waves which are reported to have been generated by a tropical cyclone.<ref name="disc2"/> * August 19, 1788 — A hurricane strikes New York City or [[Long Island]] and is reported to have left the west side of the Battery "laid in ruins" after severe flooding occurs.<ref name="disc2"/>
==1800–99== [[Image:1821 Atlantic Hurricane Track Map.png|200px|thumb|Estimated track of the [[1821 Norfolk and Long Island hurricane]]]] * October 9, 1804 — Heavy snow falls in Eastern New York peaking at 30 inches (75 cm) as a hurricane tracks northward along the East Coast and becomes [[Extratropical storm|extratropical]], as cold air fed into the system.<ref name="snow">{{cite web|author=David Ludlum|title=New England's snow hurricane of 1804 - October 6|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1804/storm2_pt3_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 5, 1815 — [[1815 North Carolina hurricane|A hurricane]] tracks over [[North Carolina]] and parallels the East Coast before producing a heavy rainstorm in New York.<ref name="1815 storm">{{cite web|author=David Ludlum|title=The North Carolina hurricane of 1815 September 1–5|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1815/storm1_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 24, 1815 — Several hundred trees fall and the majority of the fruit was stripped off apple trees just prior to harvesting time after a hurricane makes landfall on [[Long Island]].<ref name="1815 storm1">{{cite web|author=David Ludlum|title=The great September gale of 1815 September 23–24|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1815/storm2_pt1_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 16, 1816 — A possible hurricane strikes New York City, but damage remains unknown.<ref name="disc1"/> * August 9, 1817 — A tropical storm produces heavy rainfall in New York City and Long Island.<ref name="disc1"/> * September 3, 1821 — The [[1821 Norfolk and Long Island hurricane]] results in severe damage on Long Island and is accompanied by storm surge of 13 feet (4 m). High wind causes a ship to crash on Long Island killing 17 people.<ref name="disc4">{{cite web|author=David Ludlum|title=The Norfolk-Long Island hurricane, September 2–3 Pt. 2|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1821/storm1_pt2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * June 4, 1825 — A hurricane moves off the East Coast and tracks south of New York causing several ship wrecks, and killing seven people.<ref name="disc2"/> * August 27, 1827 — High tides are reported in New York City which are caused by a hurricane offshore.<ref name="1827 storm">{{cite web|author=David Ludlum|title=The Great North Carolina Hurricane of 1827 August 24–25|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1825/storm1_pt2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 1, 1830 – A hurricane passes to the east of New York and produces gale-force winds to New York City and Long Island.<ref name="1830 storm">{{cite web|author=David Ludlum|title=Twin Coastal Gales of 1830 August 1|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1830/storm1_pt2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 4, 1841 — Gale–force winds affect New York City as a hurricane tracks north along the East Coast of the United States. Damage is estimated at $2 million (1841 USD, $41 million 2007 USD).<ref name="1841 storm">{{cite web|author=David Ludlum|title=The Memorable Hurricane of 1841 October 3–4|publisher=|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1841/storm2_pt2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 13, 1846 — The [[Great Havana Hurricane of 1846]] tracks inland, causing some damage to New York City.<ref name="disc2"/> * October 6, 1849 — Severe structural damage occurs in New York City and Long Island with the passage of a hurricane to the east.<ref name="disc2"/> * July 19, 1850 — A hurricane destroys a [[Coney Island]] bath house and causes heavy rain, although damage is unknown.<ref name="disc2"/> This storm destroyed the ship Elizabeth off [[Fire Island]] and drowned American transcendentalist [[Margaret Fuller]]. * August 24, 1850 — A storm that is reported to be a hurricane affects New York and New England although there is no known damage.<ref name="disc1"/> * September 9, 1854 — A hurricane brushes the East Coast from Florida to New England causing rain on Long Island.<ref name="disc2"/> * September 16, 1858 — Low barometric pressure of 28.87 inches mercury at [[Sag Harbor]] is reported, and is thought to be associated with a tropical cyclone which causes no known damage.<ref name="disc2"/> * September 6, 1869 — A [[1869 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Six|category 3 hurricane]] makes landfall in [[Rhode Island]] and brushes Long Island, which is affected by rain, although minimal damage resulted from the storm.<ref name="disc2"/> * October 28, 1872 — A [[1872 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|tropical storm]] passes over New York City and Long Island.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} * October 1, 1874 — New York City and the Hudson Valley receives rainfall after a [[1874 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Six|minimal tropical storm]] tracked over Eastern New York.<ref name="HURDAT"/> * September 19, 1876 — The remnants of the [[1876 San Felipe hurricane|San Felipe hurricane]] track over western New York State, although damage is unknown.<ref name="HURDAT"/> * October 24, 1878 — The state is affected by [[Gale of 1878|tropical storm-force winds]] and heavy rain with the passage of a hurricane, which made landfall in [[Virginia]].<ref name="HURDAT"/><ref name="1878 storm">{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Gale of October 1878|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 3, 2008|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/galeof78.htm}}</ref> * August 22, 1888 — A [[1888 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|tropical storm]] tracks over New York City before tracking north along the East Coast of the United States.<ref name="HURDAT"/> * August 24, 1893 — [[Hog Island (New York)|Hog Island]] is washed away by strong storm surge associated with a [[1893 New York hurricane|tropical storm of unknown strength]].<ref name="disc2"/> According to HURDAT, this was a Category 1 hurricane that struck the western end of the [[Rockaway Peninsula]], passing through Brooklyn as a weakening hurricane. Manhattan Island saw gale-force winds to 56 mph. * August 29, 1893 [[1893 Sea Islands hurricane|Sea Islands hurricane]] moves thorough the Hudson Valley as a tropical storm.<ref>[http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at189306.asp?feature=image&MR=1 Sea Islands Hiurricane Track Weather Underground]</ref> Lives were lost in the Rockaways and when tow boats were destroyed at various points along the Hudson River. Roofs, structures, boats and crops were destroyed or damaged from Brooklyn to as far west as Dunkirk. Winds of 54 and 57 MPH recorded in New York and Albany respectively.<ref>[http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1891-1893/1893_1.pdf NOAA Year 1893. 48]</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gH1mAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jI0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4015,128091&dq=gale+new-york&hl=en Storm Swept Particulars of the Ruin brought by The Great Gale Many Points in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania SUFFER GREAT DAMAGE The Girard Guit September 1, 1893]</ref> * October 10, 1894 10 People were killed and 15 injured at 74 Monroe Street in Manhattan when winds blew a building under construction onto a tenement crushing it. Extensive damage in the NYC and Long Island to telegraph lines, trees and boats docked on shore. Storm formed over Gulf of Mexico as a Category 3 weakened over land in the Southeast and re strengthened to a Category 1 over the Chesapeake Bay before striking Long Island.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=k2tVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3j4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1835,5123593&dq=storm&hl=en Paterson Daily Press October 10, 1894]</ref><ref>[http://weather.newsday.com/auto/newsday/hurricane/at18945.asp Newsday Tropical Weather website] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130129191052/http://weather.newsday.com/auto/newsday/hurricane/at18945.asp |date=January 29, 2013 }}</ref>
==1900–49== [[Image:1938 Hurricane Storm Surge.jpg|200px|thumb|Storm surge from the 1938 New England hurricane]] * September 12, 1900 - Remnants of the [[1900 Galveston hurricane|Galveston hurricane]] brought tropical storm conditions to New York City and Brooklyn killing one person and damaging property.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1900/09/13/archives/city-swept-by-high-winds-the-storm-that-wrecked-galveston-reaches.html?sq=storm&scp=1 CITY SWEPT BY HIGH WINDS; The Storm that Wrecked Galveston Reaches New York. A MAN KILLED IN BROADWAY Struck by a Broken Banner Pole -- Navigation in the Bay and Rivers Difficult -- A Ferryboat's Plight New York Times September 13, 1900]</ref> * September 17, 1903 — The [[1903 Vagabond Hurricane]] produces wind gusts in excess of 65 mph (105 km/h) and 3 inches (75 mm) of rain in [[Central Park]].<ref name="nsw">{{cite web|author=North Shore WX|year=2007|title=The New Jersey Hurricane of September 16, 1903|accessdate=March 29, 2007|url=http://www.northshorewx.com/Hurricane19030916.asp|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306235419/http://northshorewx.com/hurricane19030916.asp|archivedate=March 6, 2016|df=}}</ref> * August 15, 1904 — A [[1904 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|Category 2 hurricane]] skirts the East Coast of the United States producing gale-force winds and heavy rain in Eastern New York and Long Island.<ref name="1904 MWR">{{cite web|author=Professor Cleveland Abbe|title=1904 Monthly Weather Review|year=1904|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1904.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 2, 1908 — A [[1908 Atlantic hurricane season|hurricane]] develops near North Carolina and moves northward along the coast, brushing Long Island.<ref name="1908 MWR">{{cite web|author=Professor E. B. Garriott|title=1908 Monthly Weather Review|year=1908|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 2, 2008|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1908.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * July 21, 1916 — Strong winds are reported on Long Island as a [[1916 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|category 3 hurricane]] passes to the east.<ref name="disc2"/> * August 25, 1933 — The [[1933 Chesapeake–Potomac hurricane]] produces up to 6 inches (150 mm) of rain in Southeast New York State; other damage is unknown.<ref name="1933 storm">{{cite web|author=Paul Kocin|title=Chesapeake Potomac Hurricane-August 1933|publisher=|accessdate=February 3, 2008|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/chesapeakepotomac1933.html}}</ref> * September 8, 1934 — A [[1934 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Seven|strong tropical storm]] makes landfall on Long Island.<ref name="1943 storm">{{Cite web|author=Gordon E. Dunn|title=1934 Monthly Weather Review|year=1934|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 3, 2008|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1934.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 20, 1936 — Strong waves and storm surge associated with a [[1936 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Thirteen|powerful hurricane]] floods much of [[Long Beach Island]] and causes severe beach erosion along the coast.<ref name="Buchholz et al.">{{cite book|last=Buchholz|first=Margaret|author2=Larry Savadove |year=1993|title=Great Storms of the Jersey Shore|publisher=Down the Shore Publishing|isbn=0-945582-51-X}}</ref> * September 21, 1938 — The [[New England hurricane of 1938]] (also called "The Long Island Express") makes landfall on [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]] ([[Long Island]]) as a category 3 hurricane on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]].<ref name="NOAA1">{{cite web|author=Blake, Rappaport, and Landsea|year=2006|title=The Deadliest, Costliest, and Most Intense United States Tropical Cyclones (1851 to 2006)|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=February 15, 2008|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/NWS-TPC-5.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Wind gusts of 125 mph (200 km/h) and storm surge of 18 feet (5 m) washes across part of the island.<ref name="1938 hurricane">{{Cite web|author=New York City Office of Emergency Management |title=NYC hazards:NYC hurricanes |publisher= |accessdate=February 12, 2008 |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/oem/html/hazards/storms_hurricanehistory.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217070417/http://www.nyc.gov/html/oem/html/hazards/storms_hurricanehistory.shtml |archivedate=December 17, 2007 |df= }}</ref> In New York 60 deaths and hundreds of injuries were attributed to the storm.<ref name="long island3">{{Cite web|author=Edgar W. Woolard|authorlink=Edgar W. Woolard|title=1944 Monthly Weather Review|year=1944|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 14, 2008|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1944.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> In addition, 2,600 boats and 8,900 houses are destroyed.<ref name="long island">{{Cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|title=Great New England Hurricane of 1938|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 3, 2008|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/box/hurricane/hurricane1938.shtml}}</ref> Throughout New England the hurricane killed over 682 people,<ref>{{cite news|first=R. A. |last=Scotti |title=Sudden Sea - The Great Hurricane of 1938 |publisher=Boston: Little, Brown & Co., 2003 |url=http://workingwaterfront.com/review.asp?storyID=20060436 |work= |pages= |accessdate=November 30, 2007 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070102010929/http://www.workingwaterfront.com/review.asp?storyID=20060436 |archivedate=January 2, 2007 }}</ref> damaged or destroyed over 57,000 homes, and caused property losses estimated at $4.7 billion (2005 US dollars).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/magazine/galleries/2005/0724/hurricane1938?pg=4 |title=The Great Hurricane of 1938 |accessdate=November 30, 2007 |work=The Boston Globe |publisher=Boston.com | date=July 19, 2005}}</ref> * September 14, 1944 — The [[1944 Great Atlantic hurricane]] makes landfall on Long Island as a category 1 hurricane on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]] at a high forward speed of 40 mph (64 km/h). Wind gusts of well over 100 mph (160 km/h) breaks previous wind records in New York City, while a minimum pressure reading of 28.47 inches is recorded on Long Island. 117 homes are completely destroyed, while 2,427 are severely damaged and almost 1000 businesses are destroyed or damaged. In all, six people are killed, and one person is injured.<ref name="1944 storm">{{cite web|author=Edgar W. Woolard|title=1944 Monthly Weather Review|year=1944|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 3, 2008|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1944.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 18, 1945 — A [[1945 Southeast Florida hurricane|weak tropical depression]] crosses into Southeastern New York.<ref name="HURDAT"/> * August 29, 1949 — A [[1949 Florida hurricane|tropical storm]] tracks into Central New York causing no known damage.<ref name="HURDAT"/>
==1950–74== [[File:Agnes 1972 rainfall.gif|200px|thumb|Rainfall from Hurricane Agnes (1972)]] * 1954 — [[Hurricane Hazel]] - wind gust of 113 mph at [[Battery Park]], highest ever recorded in New York City. * August 31, 1954 — [[Hurricane Carol]] makes landfall on Long Island and produces wind gusts of {{convert|120|mph|km/h}} on [[Montauk Point]].<ref name="disc2"/> On eastern [[Long Island]] near where Carol made landfall, a pressure of 960 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] is recorded.<ref name="nws">{{cite web|author1=David R. Vallee |author2=Michael R. Dion |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1997 |title=Hurricane Carol |publisher=Taunton, MA National Weather Service |accessdate=November 4, 2006 |url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/box/hurricanecarol.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050411101228/http://www.erh.noaa.gov/box/hurricanecarol.htm |archivedate=April 11, 2005 }}</ref> Winds on the island gust to 120 mph (195 km/h). The hurricane's storm surge covers the [[Montauk Highway]] in [[Montauk, New York|Montauk]], effectively isolating eastern Long Island for a period of time. Due to the compact nature of the storm, most of Long Island is largely unaffected by the hurricane.<ref name="nws"/> Specific damage totals for New York are unknown, although the storm in its entirety causes $460 million (1954 USD) in damage.<ref name="nws"/> * September 10, 1954 — [[Hurricane Edna]] tracks to the east of Long Island producing 9 inches (230 mm) of rain.<ref name="disc2"/> Prior to the storm, New York City orders an emergency standby for the majority of its hospitals, and subways.<ref name="edna2">{{Cite web|author=The Abilene Reporter-News|title=New York City May Be Sideswiped|year=1954|publisher=|accessdate=February 22, 2008|url=http://thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=84483819_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160121003055/http://thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=84483819_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=January 21, 2016|df=}}</ref> * August 13, 1955 — [[Hurricane Connie]] produces 13.24 inches (370 mm) of rain in Southeast New York, although damage is unknown.<ref name="connie">{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Hurricane Connie Rainfall Summary|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=February 3, 2008|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/connie1955.html}}</ref> * ==1975–99== * August 11, 1976 — [[Hurricane Belle]] makes landfall on Long Island as a Category 1 hurricane on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]], producing up to 6 inches (150 mm) of rain.<ref name="belle">{{cite web|author=Paul Kocin|title=Hurricane Belle Rainfall Summary|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=February 4, 2008|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/belle1976.html}}</ref> 30,000 people are evacuated in New York in anticipation of Belle. 8, 2008|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/gaston2004.html}}</ref> * September 9, 2004 — The remnants of [[Hurricane Frances]] produces heavy rainfall up to 7 inches (175 mm) which causes extensive flooding in central New York. One death, a drowning, and $6 million (2005 USD, $6.5 million 2007 USD) in damage results from the flooding.<ref name="frances">{{Cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Event Report for Hurricane Frances|year=2004|publisher=|accessdate=February 8, 2008|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~547639|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520002043/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~547639|archivedate=May 20, 2011|df=}}</ref><ref name="france">{{Cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Event report for Hurricane Frances|year=2005|publisher=|accessdate=February 8, 2008|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~547639|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520002043/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~547639|archivedate=May 20, 2011|df=}}</ref> * July 9, 2005 — The remnants of [[Hurricane Cindy (2005)|Hurricane Cindy]] produce moderate rainfall in Upstate New York causing light damage due to flooding and gusty winds, which downed some trees.<ref name="cindy">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Event report for Hurricane Cindy|year=2005|publisher=|accessdate=February 8, 2008|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~587364|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520002124/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~587364|archivedate=May 20, 2011|df=}}</ref> * August 30, 2005 — The remnants of [[Hurricane Katrina]] produce heavy rainfall up to 5 inches (125 mm) of rain in the western portion of the state. High winds also affect the state, with 4,500 people in [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] left without power after high winds downed trees and power lines.<ref name="katrina">{{Cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Event Report for Hurricane Katrina|year=2005|publisher=|accessdate=February 4, 2008|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~587589|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520002006/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~587589|archivedate=May 20, 2011|df=}}</ref> * October 5, 2005 — [[Tropical Storm Tammy]]'s remnants contribute to a rainstorm which turns into the [[Northeast U.S. flooding of October 2005]]. Up to 13 inches (325 mm) of rain cause severe flooding throughout the [[Hudson Valley]], killing 10 and causing millions of dollars in damage.<ref name="TwentytwoTCR">{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center |year=2006 |title=Tropical Cyclone Report: Subtropical Depression Twenty-Two |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=February 14, 2006 |url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL232005_Twenty-two}} |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418065801/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/tcr/AL232005_Twenty-Two.pdf |archivedate=April 18, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref name="tammy">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Tammy|year=2005|publisher=|accessdate=February 4, 2008|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~587673|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520002021/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~587673|archivedate=May 20, 2011|df=}}</ref> * September 2, 2006 — The remnants of [[Hurricane Ernesto (2006)|Hurricane Ernesto]] produce light to moderate rainfall over much of the state and wind gusts of up to {{convert|60|mph|km/h}}.<ref name="ernesto">{{Cite web|author=David Roth|title=Hurricane Erneto Rainfall Summary|publisher=|accessdate=February 4, 2008|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ernesto2006.html}}</ref> Numerous trees and powerlines are reported fallen, and several thousand people are left without power, primarily in the [[New York City]] area.<ref name="ernest2">{{Cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Event Reported for Hurricane Ernesto|year=2006|publisher=|accessdate=January 15, 2008|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626810|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520002415/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626810|archivedate=May 20, 2011|df=}}</ref> * June 5, 2007 — [[Tropical Storm Barry (2007)|Tropical Storm Barry]] produces 3.91 inches (99 mm) of rain in New York City.<ref name="wpcpa14">{{Cite web|author=Fracasso|year=2007|title=Public Advisory Number 14 for Remnants of Barry|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=June 3, 2007|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/BARRY/BARRY_14.html}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The heavy rainfall leads to flooding in the [[Finger Lakes]] region of New York State, washing out roads and driveways. Roads and several driveways were washed out.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tropical Storm Barry Event Report for New York|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=November 19, 2008|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~663237}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * September 6, 2008 — [[Hurricane Hanna]] strikes Long Island as a tropical storm with wind gusts of {{convert|52|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Shinnecock Inlet]]. Aside from numerous downed trees, damage was minimal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Record Details: Tropical Storm|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=April 16, 2010|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~741229}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * August 22, 2009 — Offshore [[Hurricane Bill (2009)|Hurricane Bill]] causes severe beach erosion and coastal damage on the southern shore of Long Island.<ref>{{cite news|author=Russell Drumm |title=Federal, State Funds Sought for Damage |date=December 3, 2009 |publisher=''The East Hampton Star'' |accessdate=April 16, 2010 |url=http://www.easthamptonstar.com/dnn/Home/News/FundsSoughtforDamage/tabid/10705/Default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229103345/http://www.easthamptonstar.com/dnn/Home/News/FundsSoughtforDamage/tabid/10705/Default.aspx |archivedate=December 29, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
==2010–present== [[Image:Hurricane irene 082811 0832 edt.jpg|200px|thumb|Hurricane Irene making landfall in New York in 2011.]] * August 27–28, 2011 — [[Hurricane Irene]] makes landfall on [[Coney Island]] as a tropical storm with winds of 70 mph (110 km/h). Storm surge reaches underneath the boardwalks in both Coney Island and Long Beach. and the [[Hudson River]] also flooded. Top recorded winds reach 70 mph at the height of the storm and left 400,000 without power. The storm also killed five people in the state and had a major impact on Upstate NY. The storm caused the National Weather Service in Albany, NY to issue a Tropical Storm Warning for the local forecast area. This had never been done before, and actually required a breach in protocol to achieve. Prior to this event, the Albany, NY forecast area was considered outside of the valid area for Tropical Storm warnings. * October 28–29, 2012- [[Hurricane Sandy]], a historic storm, makes landfall near [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]] with 70 mph winds. This storm was unusual because it was a late season hurricane combined with a Nor'easter at high tide during a full moon, producing long-lasting and devastating results not seen in generations. The largest hurricane ever recorded in the Atlantic Basin, wind gusts topped {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in some parts of the New York Metropolitan area. Sandy caused a record {{convert|14.41|ft}} storm surge at Battery Park, New York City, flooding various parts of Lower Manhattan including various tunnels and subway systems, making them inoperable for weeks. As of late 2018 some are still damaged. The immediate aftermath included widespread flooding, massive power outages and a system-wide disruption of mass transit service. Sandy had a significant effect on the digital world: 1/4 of cable, Internet, and wireless providers were unable to properly operate following the storm.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} Over nine million customers were without power, including 90 percent of Long Island and most of Manhattan below 49th Street, some for several months. Many low-lying neighborhoods in NJ and NY were completely destroyed. Thousands of homes and businesses were demolished by the record storm surge. * June 7–8, 2013 - Remnants of [[Tropical Storm Andrea (2013)|Tropical Storm Andrea]] impact New York with 4+ inches of rain and wind gusts of {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. * July 4, 2014 - [[Hurricane Arthur]] passes to the southeast of New York, producing light to moderate rainfall along the coast; however, winds remain generally below tropical storm force. Some holiday celebrations in the New York metropolitan area were canceled or postponed. * June 21–22, 2015 - The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Bill (2015)|Tropical Storm Bill]] pass through Upstate New York, producing heavy rain. * May 28, 2016 - [[Tropical Storm Bonnie]] brings heavy rain up to the Northeast coast * October 9–10, 2016 - [[Hurricane Matthew]] interacts with a frontal system, bringing heavy rain and minor flooding to the state. * June 19, 2017 - The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Cindy (2017)|Tropical Storm Cindy]] producing severe thunderstorms and EF-0 tornadoes around the Tri-State Area * September 19–20, 2017 - [[Tropical Storm Jose]] passes Long Island closely, producing heavy wind and rain * September 27, 2017 - [[Hurricane Maria]] brings showers and some gusty winds to the shore. * October 28–30, 2017 - [[Tropical Storm Philippe]] interacts with a low pressure system, bringing high winds and heavy rain to the Northeast. *September 8-9, 2018 - The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Gordon (2018)|Tropical Storm Gordon]] which had previously been absorbed by another system bring minor flooding to NYC * [[Hurricane Michael]] interacts with a cold front and brings heavy rain and gusty winds to NYC and Long Island.

{{orphan|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Nedjib (Ned) Djilali |image=Nedjib Djilali.jpg |alt = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|year=1953|month=8|day=1|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Algiers]]，[[Algeria]] |fields = [[Energy modeling]]; [[fuel cell]]; [[transport phenomena]]; [[computational fluid dynamics]] |alma_mater = Lycée Technique d’Alger, [[University of Hertfordshire]], [[Imperial College]], [[University of British Columbia]] |awards = Ludwig Mond Prize , Institution of Mechanical Engineers (UK) {{small|(1998)}}
Fellow, Canadian Society for Mechanical Engineering {{small|(2003)}}
Fellow,[[Canadian Academy of Engineering]]{{small|(2010)}}
Honorary Professor, [[Tianjin University]]{{small|(2013)}}
Fellow, [[Royal Society of Canada]]{{small|(2013)}}
Highly Cited Researcher{{small|(2014; 2015)}}
Jules Stachiewicz Medal , Canadian Society for Mechanical Engineering {{small|(2017)}}
David H. Turpin Gold Medal for Career Achievement in Research , University of Victoria {{small|(2018)}} }} '''Nedjib (Ned) Djilali''' (born August 1, 1953) is a Canadian engineering professor and researcher specializing in sustainable energy and thermofluid sciences. He holds the [[Canada Research Chair]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.chairs-chaires.gc.ca/chairholders-titulaires/profile-eng.aspx?profileId=1976|title=Canada Research Chairs|last=Government of Canada|first=Industry Canada|date=2012-11-29|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-18}} in Advanced Energy Systems Design and Computational Modelling{{Cite web|url=https://ece.nl/wp-content/uploads/Thomson-Reuters-2015.pdf|title=The World's Most Influential Scientific Minds 2015|last=|first=|date=2015-12-01|website=ece.nl|publisher=Thomson Reuters|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-18}} at the University of Victoria. Djilali is a Highly Cited Researcher,{{Cite web|url=https://clarivate.com/hcr/researchers-list/archived-lists/|title=Archived Lists - HCR|last=|first=|date=|website=Clarivate Analytics|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-13}} and a fellow of both the [[Canadian Academy of Engineering]] (2010) and the [[Royal Society of Canada]] (2013).{{Cite web|url=https://rsc-src.ca/sites/default/files/pdf/2013%20New%20Fellows%20Citations_2.pdf|title=2013 List of New Fellows|last=|first=|date=2013-09-06|website=Royal Society of Canada|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-18}} ==Biography== {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2018}} Djilali was born and raised in Algeria and educated in the UK and Canada. After completing a BSc (Hon.) in Aeronautical Engineering at the [[University of Hertfordshire]] and a MSc in Aeronautics at [[Imperial College]], London he served with the Air Force (compulsory military service) and then worked as an airworthiness engineer and as a lecturer at the Ecole Nationale des Techniques de l'Aviation Civile, Algeria. He moved to Canada in 1982, earned a PhD in experimental and [[computational fluid dynamics]] from the [[University of British Columbia]] in 1987, and joined the Advanced Aerodynamics Department of [[Bombardier Aerospace]], Montreal in 1989, where he worked on the design of the [[Canadair Regional Jet]] and on the development of advanced [[Computational fluid dynamics|CFD]] methods. He was appointed at the [[University of Victoria]] in 1991. ==Work== Prof. Djilali’s earliest work focused on computational and experimental [[fluid mechanics]] and [[heat transfer]], including fundamental aspects of complex [[turbulence]], thermosolutal transport in [[epitaxial crystal growth]] of semiconductors, and [[membrane separation]] processes for [[desalination]] and [[water purification]]. He is particularly known for his contributions to [[fuel cell]] science and technology,{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=Fall 2016|title=Ned Djilali: A Fuel Cell Guru|url=http://csme-scgm.ca/sites/default/files/BULLETIN-FALL-2016.pdf|journal=The Canadian Society for Mechanical Engineering Bulletin|volume=|pages=19-20|via=csme-scgm.ca}} and for his work on sustainable [[energy modeling]]. His seminal work includes pioneering computational modeling of [[transport phenomena]] in fuel cells,{{Cite journal|last=Djilali|first=N.|date=2007-04-01|title=Computational modelling of polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cells: Challenges and opportunities|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0360544206002246|journal=Energy|volume=32|issue=4|pages=269–280|doi=10.1016/j.energy.2006.08.007|issn=0360-5442|via=}} and novel fuel cell architectures.{{Cite journal|date=2008|title=Research Highlights|url=http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=b805061a|journal=Lab on a Chip|language=en|volume=8|issue=5|pages=645|doi=10.1039/b805061a|issn=1473-0197}}{{Cite web|url=https://patentimages.storage.googleapis.com/4d/91/5f/eb8e61b9b71afe/US8551637.pdf|title=United States Patent No. US 8,551,637 B2|last=|first=|date=2013-10-08|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} His energy systems analysis work has focused on [[demand response]] methods to achieve high penetration of [[renewable energy]] in electric power systems, and the [[water-energy nexus]].{{Cite news|url=http://theclimateexaminer.ca/2016/04/21/when-the-glaciers-go-hydroelectric-vulnerability-and-climate-change/|title=When the glaciers go: Hydroelectric vulnerability and climate change|last=|first=|date=2016-04-21|work=The Climate Examiner|access-date=2018-03-20|language=en-US}} Djilali has served as Director of UVic’s Institute for Integrated Energy Systems and of the Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions, leading and facilitating the development and implementation of low carbon energy systems, and forming collaborative partnerships with automotive and clean energy technology companies and organizations around the world including [[Ballard Power Systems|Ballard]], [[Toyota]], [[AECL]], and CFD Research Corporation. Djilali was a member of the task force that developed the “BC Hydrogen & Fuel Cell Industry Strategy” reporting to the Premier’s Technology Council. He was a High Level Visiting Researcher with the CNRS [[Institut de Mécanique des Fluides de Toulouse]] (France) in 1997-1998, an ERCOFTAC visiting Fellow with ETH in 2003, a Visiting Professor with the [[National Research Council (Canada)|NRC]] Institute for Fuel Cell Innovation in 2004, a Professor in Residence with Angstrom Power Inc. in 2005, and a Visiting Professor with NEXT Energy, [[University of Oldenburg]] in 2016. Djilali was also appointed Guest Professor at [[Chongqing University]] and [[Shanghai University]], and Honorary Professor at [[Tianjin University]]. He was a member of the founding editorial board of the [[ASME]] Journal of Fuel Cell Science & Technology (now Journal of Electrochemical Energy Conversion and Storage),{{Cite web|url=http://electrochemical.asmedigitalcollection.asme.org/journal.aspx?journalid=123|title=Journal of Electrochemical Energy Conversion and Storage {{!}} ASME DC|last=|first=|date=|website=electrochemical.asmedigitalcollection.asme.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-20}}{{Failed verification|date=May 2018}} and served on the board of several other journals.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} Prof. Djilali was President of the CFD Society of Canada from 2000-2002,{{Cite web|url=http://www.cfdcanada.ca/about-us/past-presidents/|title=Past Presidents {{!}} CFD Society of Canada|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cfdcanada.ca|language=en-CA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-18}} and chaired the CFD97 Conference and ISTP-20 (Int. Symposium on Transport Phenomena).{{Cite web|url=http://pctfe.pu-toyama.ac.jp/istphi.html|title=Pacific Center of Thermal-Fluids Engineering (PCTFE)|last=|first=|date=|website=pctfe.pu-toyama.ac.jp|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-20}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://scholar.google.ca/citations?user=TcpC3GgAAAAJ&hl=en Ned Djilali at Google Scholar] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-3xzdPAWB4I Faces of UVic] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-3xzdPAWB4I Distinguished Lecture Series], York University *[http://iesvic.uvic.ca/ Institute for Integrated Energy Systems], University of Victoria *[http://www.pics.uvic.ca/ Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions] *[https://www.scientistsclub.org/Applied Energy Unilab]: Distributed Energy and Microgrids (DEM) [[Category:ISI highly cited researchers]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Canada]] [[Category:Computational fluid dynamicists]] [[Category:University of Victoria faculty]] [[Category:Canadian people of Algerian descent]] [[Category:Sustainable energy]] [[Category:Fuel cells]]
